snippet: Banks in Europe and China announced measures to address concern about waning economic growth, a response that was all the more striking because it was uncoordinated.
abstract: Central banks in Europe and China announce measures to address waning economic growth, a response that is all the more striking because it was uncoordinated; China’s central bank unexpectedly cuts regulated bank lending rates for the second time in four weeks; the European Central Bank cuts its benchmark interest rate to 0.75 percent, the lowest level in its 14-year history; and the Bank of England announces it will expand its holdings of government bonds by about 15 percent.

byline.contributor: Reporting was contributed by Keith Bradsher in Hong Kong, Melissa Eddy in Frankfurt, Stephen Castle in London and Jack Ewing in Manahawkin, N.J.

lead_paragraph: Banks in Europe and China announced measures to address concern about waning economic growth, a response that was all the more striking because it was uncoordinated.

headline.seo: Central Banks Move to Spur Economy on 3 Fronts
headline.main: Three Central Banks Act to Stimulate More Borrowing
headline.print_headline: 3 Central Banks Act To Stimulate More Borrowing
